information.name: El Parque del laberinto
information.description: A hedge garden maze in northern Barcelona. If you need an escape from the hustle and bustle of the cramped city life, go to el laberinto. On Wednesday mornings, it is free, and hardly anyone else goes in the middle of the week. Families pack it during the weekends, especially on Sunday.
information.location: Passeig dels Castanyers 1 | Carrer de l'Arquitectura, 08035 Barcelona, Spain

q1.question: How do you ask for help if you are lost in the maze?

q2.question: How do you hit on someone cute in the maze?
options: Dime cuando sales esta noche, me voy contigo.

q3.question: How do you ask 'How much does it cost to get into the park?'

comments.name: Hannah Aurand
comments.comment: Me encantaba pasear por el laberinto y perderme sola.

information.name: Barceloneta
information.description: The tourist's beach in Barcelona. If you're in Barcelona during any month with weather above 60 degrees, you'll see the snowbirds come down from the great white north to enjoy the mediterranean heat. Don't be surprised by nudity on this beach. If you'd like to escape the tourist traps, move further down the beach away from the metro stop, toward Nova Icária or Platja Bogatell.

q1.question: A man comes up and offers to sell you a 5 euro mojito on the beach. What do you say to him?
options: Te daré diez euros si me dejes en paz.

q2.question: A woman comes up and offers you a massage on the beach. What do you say? (This does happen, and they can be persistent.)
options: Sí, entre los hombros por favor.

q3.question: You run into some tourists who have decided to forgo bathing suits on the beach. What do you do?
options: Buy a mojito to desensitize yourself to the view.
Remain calm and try not to stare. This is Europe.
q3.answer: Remain calm and try not to stare. This is Europe.

comments.name: Hannah Aurand
comments.comment: Siempre paseaba el la arena al lado de las olas del mar...
